trans-unit.source: In addition to using voice commands within Cortana to access system features, you can also use voice commands through Cortana to launch a foreground app and specify an action or command to execute within the app.
trans-unit.target: In addition to using voice commands within Cortana to access system features, you can also use voice commands through Cortana to launch a foreground app and specify an action or command to execute within the app.

trans-unit.source: Launch a foreground app with voice commands in Cortana
trans-unit.target: Launch a foreground app with voice commands in Cortana

trans-unit.source: Launch a foreground app with voice commands in Cortana
trans-unit.target: Launch a foreground app with voice commands in Cortana

trans-unit.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
trans-unit.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

trans-unit.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132) \]
trans-unit.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132) \]

trans-unit.source: Important APIs
trans-unit.target: Important APIs

trans-unit.source: Windows.ApplicationModel.VoiceCommands
trans-unit.target: Windows.ApplicationModel.VoiceCommands

trans-unit.source: VCD elements and attributes v1.2
trans-unit.target: VCD elements and attributes v1.2

trans-unit.source: In addition to using voice commands within **Cortana** to access system features, you can also use voice commands through **Cortana** to launch a foreground app and specify an action or command to execute within the app.
trans-unit.target: In addition to using voice commands within **Cortana** to access system features, you can also use voice commands through **Cortana** to launch a foreground app and specify an action or command to execute within the app.

trans-unit.source: Note
trans-unit.target: Note

trans-unit.source: A voice command is a single utterance with a specific intent, defined in a Voice Command Definition (VCD) file, directed at an installed app through **Cortana**.
trans-unit.target: A voice command is a single utterance with a specific intent, defined in a Voice Command Definition (VCD) file, directed at an installed app through **Cortana**.

trans-unit.source: A voice command definition can vary in complexity.
trans-unit.target: A voice command definition can vary in complexity.

trans-unit.source: It can support anything from a single, constrained utterance to a collection of more flexible, natural language utterances, all denoting the same intent.
trans-unit.target: It can support anything from a single, constrained utterance to a collection of more flexible, natural language utterances, all denoting the same intent.

trans-unit.source: A VCD file defines one or more voice commands, each with a unique intent.
trans-unit.target: A VCD file defines one or more voice commands, each with a unique intent.

trans-unit.source: The target app can be launched in the foreground (the app takes focus) or activated in the background (**Cortana** retains focus but provides results from the app), depending on the complexity of the interaction.
trans-unit.target: The target app can be launched in the foreground (the app takes focus) or activated in the background (**Cortana** retains focus but provides results from the app), depending on the complexity of the interaction.

trans-unit.source: For example, voice commands that require additional context or user input (such as sending a message to a specific contact) are best handled in a foreground app, while basic commands can be handled in **Cortana** through a background app.
trans-unit.target: For example, voice commands that require additional context or user input (such as sending a message to a specific contact) are best handled in a foreground app, while basic commands can be handled in **Cortana** through a background app.

trans-unit.source: We demonstrate these features here with a trip planning and management app named **Adventure Works**.
trans-unit.target: We demonstrate these features here with a trip planning and management app named **Adventure Works**.

trans-unit.source: To create a new **Adventure Works** trip without **Cortana**, a user would launch the app and navigate to the **New trip** page.
trans-unit.target: To create a new **Adventure Works** trip without **Cortana**, a user would launch the app and navigate to the **New trip** page.

trans-unit.source: To view an existing trip, a user would launch the app, navigate to the **Upcoming trips** page, and select the trip.
trans-unit.target: To view an existing trip, a user would launch the app, navigate to the **Upcoming trips** page, and select the trip.

trans-unit.source: Using voice commands through **Cortana**, the user can instead just say, "Adventure Works add a trip" or "Add a trip on Adventure Works" to launch the app and navigate to the **New trip** page.
trans-unit.target: Using voice commands through **Cortana**, the user can instead just say, "Adventure Works add a trip" or "Add a trip on Adventure Works" to launch the app and navigate to the **New trip** page.

trans-unit.source: In turn, saying "Adventure Works, show my trip to London" will launch the app and navigate to the **Trip** detail page, shown here.
trans-unit.target: In turn, saying "Adventure Works, show my trip to London" will launch the app and navigate to the **Trip** detail page, shown here.

trans-unit.source: cortana launching foreground app
trans-unit.target: cortana launching foreground app

trans-unit.source: These are the basic steps to add voice-command functionality and integrate Cortana with your app using speech or keyboard input:
trans-unit.target: These are the basic steps to add voice-command functionality and integrate Cortana with your app using speech or keyboard input:

trans-unit.source: Create a VCD file.
trans-unit.target: Create a VCD file.

trans-unit.source: This is an XML document that defines all the spoken commands that the user can say to initiate actions or invoke commands when activating your app.
trans-unit.target: This is an XML document that defines all the spoken commands that the user can say to initiate actions or invoke commands when activating your app.

trans-unit.source: See [**VCD elements and attributes v1.2**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn706593).
trans-unit.target: See [**VCD elements and attributes v1.2**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn706593).

trans-unit.source: Register the command sets in the VCD file when the app is launched.
trans-unit.target: Register the command sets in the VCD file when the app is launched.

trans-unit.source: Handle the activation-by-voice-command, navigation within the app, and execution of the command.
trans-unit.target: Handle the activation-by-voice-command, navigation within the app, and execution of the command.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites:
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites:

trans-unit.source: If you're new to developing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps, have a look through these topics to get familiar with the technologies discussed here.
trans-unit.target: If you're new to developing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps, have a look through these topics to get familiar with the technologies discussed here.

trans-unit.source: Create your first app
trans-unit.target: Create your first app

trans-unit.source: Learn about events with [Events and routed events overview](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/mt185584)
trans-unit.target: Learn about events with [Events and routed events overview](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/mt185584)

trans-unit.source: User experience guidelines:
trans-unit.target: User experience guidelines:

trans-unit.source: See [Cortana design guidelines](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn974233) for info about how to integrate your app with **Cortana** and [Speech design guidelines](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn596121) for helpful tips on designing a useful and engaging speech-enabled app.
trans-unit.target: See [Cortana design guidelines](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn974233) for info about how to integrate your app with **Cortana** and [Speech design guidelines](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn596121) for helpful tips on designing a useful and engaging speech-enabled app.

trans-unit.source: Create a VCD file
trans-unit.target: Create a VCD file

trans-unit.source: In Microsoft Visual Studio, right-click the project name, select Add->New Item, and then select **XML File**.
trans-unit.target: In Microsoft Visual Studio, right-click the project name, select Add->New Item, and then select **XML File**.

trans-unit.source: Type a name for the VCD file.
trans-unit.target: Type a name for the VCD file.

trans-unit.source: For example, "AdventureWorksCommands.xml".
trans-unit.target: For example, "AdventureWorksCommands.xml".

trans-unit.source: Select **Add**.
trans-unit.target: Select **Add**.

trans-unit.source: In **Solution Explorer**, select the VCD file.
trans-unit.target: In **Solution Explorer**, select the VCD file.

trans-unit.source: In the **Properties** window, set **Build action** to **Content**, and then set **Copy to output directory** to **Copy if newer**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Properties** window, set **Build action** to **Content**, and then set **Copy to output directory** to **Copy if newer**.

trans-unit.source: Edit the VCD file
trans-unit.target: Edit the VCD file

trans-unit.source: For each language supported by your app, create a **CommandSet** of voice commands that your app can handle.
trans-unit.target: For each language supported by your app, create a **CommandSet** of voice commands that your app can handle.

trans-unit.source: Each **Command** declared in a VCD file must include this information:
trans-unit.target: Each **Command** declared in a VCD file must include this information:

trans-unit.source: A command Name used by the application to identify the voice command at runtime.
trans-unit.target: A command Name used by the application to identify the voice command at runtime.

trans-unit.source: An **Example** element that contains a phrase describing how a user can invoke the command.
trans-unit.target: An **Example** element that contains a phrase describing how a user can invoke the command.

trans-unit.source: **Cortana** shows this example when the user says "What can I say?", "Help", or they tap **See more**.
trans-unit.target: **Cortana** shows this example when the user says "What can I say?", "Help", or they tap **See more**.

trans-unit.source: A **ListenFor** element that contains the words or phrases that your app recognizes to initiate a command.
trans-unit.target: A **ListenFor** element that contains the words or phrases that your app recognizes to initiate a command.

trans-unit.source: Each command needs to have at least one **ListenFor** element.
trans-unit.target: Each command needs to have at least one **ListenFor** element.

trans-unit.source: A **Feedback** element that contains the text for **Cortana** to display and speak as the application is launched.
trans-unit.target: A **Feedback** element that contains the text for **Cortana** to display and speak as the application is launched.

trans-unit.source: A **Navigate** element to indicate that the voice command is to launch the app in the foreground.
trans-unit.target: A **Navigate** element to indicate that the voice command is to launch the app in the foreground.

trans-unit.source: Specify a **VoiceCommandService** element if the voice command launches the app in the background instead.
trans-unit.target: Specify a **VoiceCommandService** element if the voice command launches the app in the background instead.

trans-unit.source: For more details, see [Launch a background app with voice commands in Cortana](launch-a-background-app-with-voice-commands-in-cortana.md).
trans-unit.target: For more details, see [Launch a background app with voice commands in Cortana](launch-a-background-app-with-voice-commands-in-cortana.md).

trans-unit.source: For more detail, see the [**VCD elements and attributes v1.2**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn706593) reference.
trans-unit.target: For more detail, see the [**VCD elements and attributes v1.2**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn706593) reference.

trans-unit.source: You can specify multiple language versions for the commands used to activate your app and execute a command.
trans-unit.target: You can specify multiple language versions for the commands used to activate your app and execute a command.

trans-unit.source: You can create multiple **CommandSet** elements, each with a different **xml:lang** attribute to allow your app to be used in different markets.
trans-unit.target: You can create multiple **CommandSet** elements, each with a different **xml:lang** attribute to allow your app to be used in different markets.

trans-unit.source: For example, an app for the United States might have a **CommandSet** for English and a **CommandSet** for Spanish.
trans-unit.target: For example, an app for the United States might have a **CommandSet** for English and a **CommandSet** for Spanish.

trans-unit.source: Caution
trans-unit.target: Caution

trans-unit.source: To activate an app and initiate an action using a voice command, the app must register a VCD file that contains a **CommandSet** with a language that matches the speech language that the user selected on their device.
trans-unit.target: To activate an app and initiate an action using a voice command, the app must register a VCD file that contains a **CommandSet** with a language that matches the speech language that the user selected on their device.

trans-unit.source: This language is set by the user on the device Settings > System > Speech > Speech Language screen.
trans-unit.target: This language is set by the user on the device Settings > System > Speech > Speech Language screen.

trans-unit.source: Here's a VCD file that defines a voice command for the **Adventure Works** app.
trans-unit.target: Here's a VCD file that defines a voice command for the **Adventure Works** app.

trans-unit.source: For this example, **CommandPrefix** is set to "Adventure Works", **Command**, identified by Name (" showTripToDestination"), specifies both what the user can say and what feedback is provided by Cortana, **ListenFor** specifies the text that can be recognized (with a reference to a **PhraseList** element that constrains the recognized destinations), **Navigate** indicates that the voice command is handled by launching the app in the foreground, and **Feedback** specifies what the user will hear when **Cortana** launches the app.
trans-unit.target: For this example, **CommandPrefix** is set to "Adventure Works", **Command**, identified by Name (" showTripToDestination"), specifies both what the user can say and what feedback is provided by Cortana, **ListenFor** specifies the text that can be recognized (with a reference to a **PhraseList** element that constrains the recognized destinations), **Navigate** indicates that the voice command is handled by launching the app in the foreground, and **Feedback** specifies what the user will hear when **Cortana** launches the app.

trans-unit.source: **ListenFor** elements cannot be programmatically modified.
trans-unit.target: **ListenFor** elements cannot be programmatically modified.

trans-unit.source: However, **PhraseList** elements associated with **ListenFor** elements can be programmatically modified.
trans-unit.target: However, **PhraseList** elements associated with **ListenFor** elements can be programmatically modified.

trans-unit.source: Applications should modify the content of the **PhraseList** at runtime based on the data set generated as the user uses the app.
trans-unit.target: Applications should modify the content of the **PhraseList** at runtime based on the data set generated as the user uses the app.

trans-unit.source: See [How to dynamically modify VCD phrase lists](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn747872).
trans-unit.target: See [How to dynamically modify VCD phrase lists](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn747872).

trans-unit.source: Install the VCD commands
trans-unit.target: Install the VCD commands

trans-unit.source: Your app must run once to install the command sets in the VCD.
trans-unit.target: Your app must run once to install the command sets in the VCD.

trans-unit.source: When your app is activated, call [**InstallCommandDefinitionsFromStorageFileAsync**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn708205) in the [**OnLaunched**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br242335) handler to register the commands that the system should listen for.
trans-unit.target: When your app is activated, call [**InstallCommandDefinitionsFromStorageFileAsync**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn708205) in the [**OnLaunched**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br242335) handler to register the commands that the system should listen for.

trans-unit.source: **Note** If a device backup occurs and your app reinstalls automatically, voice command data is not preserved.
trans-unit.target: **Note** If a device backup occurs and your app reinstalls automatically, voice command data is not preserved.

trans-unit.source: To ensure the voice command data for your app stays intact, consider initializing your VCD file each time your app launches or activates, or store a setting that indicates if the VCD is currently installed and check the setting each time your app launches or activates.
trans-unit.target: To ensure the voice command data for your app stays intact, consider initializing your VCD file each time your app launches or activates, or store a setting that indicates if the VCD is currently installed and check the setting each time your app launches or activates.

trans-unit.source: Here's an example that shows how to install the commands specified by a VCD file (vcd.xml).
trans-unit.target: Here's an example that shows how to install the commands specified by a VCD file (vcd.xml).

trans-unit.source: Handle activation and execute voice commands
trans-unit.target: Handle activation and execute voice commands

trans-unit.source: Once your app has been launched and the voice command sets installed, specify how your app responds to subsequent voice command activations.
trans-unit.target: Once your app has been launched and the voice command sets installed, specify how your app responds to subsequent voice command activations.

trans-unit.source: For example, your app might navigate to a specific page of content, display a map or other navigation utility, or speak a confirmation or status.
trans-unit.target: For example, your app might navigate to a specific page of content, display a map or other navigation utility, or speak a confirmation or status.

trans-unit.source: You need to:
trans-unit.target: You need to:

trans-unit.source: Confirm that your app was activated by a voice command.
trans-unit.target: Confirm that your app was activated by a voice command.

trans-unit.source: Override the [**Application.OnActivated**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br242330) event and check whether [**IActivatedEventArgs**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br224727).[**Kind**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br224728) is [**VoiceCommand**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br224693).
trans-unit.target: Override the [**Application.OnActivated**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br242330) event and check whether [**IActivatedEventArgs**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br224727).[**Kind**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br224728) is [**VoiceCommand**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br224693).

trans-unit.source: Determine the name of the command and what was spoken.
trans-unit.target: Determine the name of the command and what was spoken.

trans-unit.source: Get a reference to a [**VoiceCommandActivatedEventArgs**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn609755) object from the [**IActivatedEventArgs**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br224727) and query the [**Result**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn609758) property for a [**SpeechRecognitionResult**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn631432) object.
trans-unit.target: Get a reference to a [**VoiceCommandActivatedEventArgs**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn609755) object from the [**IActivatedEventArgs**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br224727) and query the [**Result**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn609758) property for a [**SpeechRecognitionResult**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn631432) object.

trans-unit.source: To determine what the user said, check the value of [**Text**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn631441) or the semantic properties of the recognized phrase in the [**SpeechRecognitionSemanticInterpretation**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn631443) dictionary.
trans-unit.target: To determine what the user said, check the value of [**Text**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn631441) or the semantic properties of the recognized phrase in the [**SpeechRecognitionSemanticInterpretation**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn631443) dictionary.

trans-unit.source: Take the appropriate action in your app, typically navigating to the relevant page.
trans-unit.target: Take the appropriate action in your app, typically navigating to the relevant page.

trans-unit.source: For this example, we refer back to the VCD in Step 3: Edit the VCD file.
trans-unit.target: For this example, we refer back to the VCD in Step 3: Edit the VCD file.

trans-unit.source: Once we get the speech-recognition result for the voice command, we get the command name from the first value in the [**RulePath**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn631438) array.
trans-unit.target: Once we get the speech-recognition result for the voice command, we get the command name from the first value in the [**RulePath**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn631438) array.

trans-unit.source: As the VCD file defined more than one possible voice command, we need to compare the value against the command names in the VCD and take the appropriate action.
trans-unit.target: As the VCD file defined more than one possible voice command, we need to compare the value against the command names in the VCD and take the appropriate action.

trans-unit.source: The most common action an application can take is to navigate to a page with content relevant to the context of the voice command.
trans-unit.target: The most common action an application can take is to navigate to a page with content relevant to the context of the voice command.

trans-unit.source: For this example, we navigate to a **TripPage** page and pass in the value of the voice command, how the command was input, and the recognized "destination" phrase (if applicable).
trans-unit.target: For this example, we navigate to a **TripPage** page and pass in the value of the voice command, how the command was input, and the recognized "destination" phrase (if applicable).

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, the app could send a navigation parameter to the [**SpeechRecognitionResult**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn631432) when navigating to the page.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, the app could send a navigation parameter to the [**SpeechRecognitionResult**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn631432) when navigating to the page.

trans-unit.source: You can find out whether the voice command that launched your app was actually spoken, or whether it was typed in as text, from the [**SpeechRecognitionSemanticInterpretation.Properties**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn631445) dictionary using the **commandMode** key.
trans-unit.target: You can find out whether the voice command that launched your app was actually spoken, or whether it was typed in as text, from the [**SpeechRecognitionSemanticInterpretation.Properties**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn631445) dictionary using the **commandMode** key.

trans-unit.source: The value of that key will be either "voice" or "text".
trans-unit.target: The value of that key will be either "voice" or "text".

trans-unit.source: If the value of the key is "voice", consider using speech synthesis ([**Windows.Media.SpeechSynthesis**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn278951)) to provide the user with spoken feedback.
trans-unit.target: If the value of the key is "voice", consider using speech synthesis ([**Windows.Media.SpeechSynthesis**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn278951)) to provide the user with spoken feedback.

trans-unit.source: Use the [**SpeechRecognitionSemanticInterpretation.Properties**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn631445) to find out the content spoken in the **PhraseList** or **PhraseTopic** constraints of a **ListenFor** element.
trans-unit.target: Use the [**SpeechRecognitionSemanticInterpretation.Properties**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn631445) to find out the content spoken in the **PhraseList** or **PhraseTopic** constraints of a **ListenFor** element.

trans-unit.source: The dictionary key is the value of the **Label** attribute of the **PhraseList** or **PhraseTopic** element.
trans-unit.target: The dictionary key is the value of the **Label** attribute of the **PhraseList** or **PhraseTopic** element.

trans-unit.source: Here, we show how to access the value of **{destination}** phrase.
trans-unit.target: Here, we show how to access the value of **{destination}** phrase.
